TEXT: The applicant , ORG , is a NORP national , born in DATE and living in GPE , GPE . In the proceedings before the ORG , the applicant is represented by PERSON , a lawyer practising in GPE , GPE . The respondent Government are represented by their Agent Mr PERSON , of ORG .
The facts of the case , as submitted by the parties , may be summarised as follows .

On CARDINAL DATE the ORG ( Sąd Rejonowy ) sentenced the applicant to DATE and QUANTITY months’ imprisonment . It deducted the period spent by the applicant in detention on remand from his sentence . In consequence , the applicant served that sentence during the following periods : from DATE to CARDINAL DATE ; from CARDINAL to DATE ; from DATE to CARDINAL DATE and from DATE to DATE .
On DATE the ORG ( PERSON ) released the applicant on probation for DATE . Shortly afterwards , the applicant asked the court to prolong his release for a further , unspecified term .

On DATE the applicant was arrested by the police on suspicion of having committed robbery . On DATE he was brought before ORG ( Prokurator Rejonowy ) , charged with robbery and detained on remand in view of the reasonable suspicion that he had committed the offence with which he had been charged . On DATE the ORG rejected his application for the prolongation of his release , on the ground that he had been remanded in custody on suspicion of having committed a new , serious offence .
On DATE ORG , on an appeal by the applicant , upheld the detention order of DATE and the reasons therefor .

On DATE the applicant made an application for release , submitting that his detention lacked any basis because the investigating prosecutor had not admitted evidence proposed by him . That application was dismissed by ORG on DATE and , on appeal , by ORG ( Prokurator Wojewódzki ) on DATE . The authorities held that there was a reasonable suspicion that the applicant had committed the offence in question and that his detention was necessary in order to ensure the proper conduct of the proceedings .

On DATE the applicant filed a subsequent application for release . It was dismissed on DATE by ORG and , on appeal , by ORG on DATE . The prosecutors at both instances considered that the grounds originally given for his detention were still valid .

On DATE ORG prolonged the applicant ’s pre - trial detention until DATE . On DATE the court extended his detention until DATE . Those decisions , on an appeal by the applicant , were upheld by ORG on DATE .
On DATE the applicant complained to the investigating prosecutor that correspondence he received from ORG was being opened and censored .
On DATE the ORG lodged a bill of indictment with ORG .

In the meantime , on an unspecified date , the applicant filed CARDINAL further applications for release . They were dismissed on DATE and DATE by ORG and on DATE by ORG ( Sąd Apelacyjny ) . The courts held that the serious nature of the offences with which he had been charged justified the continued detention .
On a later unknown date , the trial court granted the applicant ’s application for an officially - appointed lawyer .

On DATE ORG dismissed the applicant ’s subsequent application for release . That decision was upheld on appeal on DATE . The courts reiterated the previous grounds given for the applicant ’s detention .
On DATE ORG convicted the applicant as charged and sentenced him to DATE and CARDINAL months’ imprisonment , a fine and deprivation of his civic rights for DATE .

In the meantime , on an unspecified date , the applicant again asked the court to release him . The application was dismissed on DATE in view of the fact that his detention pending appeal was mandatory under LAW because the first - instance sentence exceeded CARDINAL years’ imprisonment .
On DATE ORG , on an appeal by the applicant , quashed the first - instance judgment and remitted the case .

On DATE the applicant ’s case was transferred to ORG because , under amendments to LAW , as from DATE a district court was competent to deal with such cases . The trial was held on CARDINAL and DATE .

On DATE the ORG convicted the applicant of robbery and sentenced him to DATE imprisonment , a fine and deprivation of his civic rights for DATE . The court deducted the period of the applicant ’s detention on remand from DATE and DATE from his sentence . The applicant appealed .
On DATE the applicant asked ORG to quash the order for his detention . The application was dismissed on DATE .
On DATE the ORG heard the applicant ’s appeal and upheld the first - instance judgment .

On DATE the applicant lodged a notice of a cassation appeal with ORG . On DATE he asked that court to appoint a lawyer for him in order to assist him in cassation proceedings . He submitted that he had no occupation and income , and that he could not bear the costs of his defence . He also stressed that under the relevant provisions of the Code of Criminal Procedure a cassation appeal had to be filed and signed by an advocate . On DATE the applicant made yet another application for legal assistance .

On DATE the court rejected the application , finding that the applicant had not proved that he could not afford legal assistance , namely , that the costs of legal assistance would entail a substantial reduction of his and his family ’s standard of living , as defined in LAW .

On DATE the applicant made a subsequent application for legal assistance . He submitted documentary evidence showing his difficult financial situation . On DATE ORG granted the application and , on DATE , appointed a lawyer for the applicant . On a later unknown date in DATE or DATE , the applicant ’s officially - appointed lawyer filed a cassation appeal .
On DATE ORG ( Sąd Najwyższy ) heard the appeal and rejected it as obviously lacking any basis .

At the material time the rules governing detention on remand were contained in LAW of the Law of DATE – Code of Criminal Procedure ( Kodeks postępowania karnego ) ( “ the Code ” ) – entitled “ Preventive measures ” ( NORP zapobiegawcze ) . The LAW is no longer in force . It was repealed and replaced by LAW DATE ( commonly referred to as the “ GPE Procedure ” ) , which entered into force on DATE .

Pursuant to LAW ( in the version applicable at the material time ) , the prosecutor was authorised to detain a suspect on remand , provided that such person had previously been charged and heard by that prosecutor .

At the relevant time the LAW set out CARDINAL different legal avenues whereby a detainee could challenge the lawfulness of his detention and obtain release : an appeal to a court against a detention order made by a prosecutor ; proceedings in which courts examined applications for prolongation of detention made by a prosecutor during an investigation ; and proceedings relating to the detainee ’s applications for release .
As regards the last of these , LAW provided the following :
“ An accused may at any time apply to have a preventive measure lifted or varied .
Such an application shall be decided by the prosecutor or , after the bill of indictment has been lodged , by the court competent to deal with the case , within a period not exceeding DATE . ”

Under LAW , an accused who had proved that he could not afford legal assistance ( i.e. that the costs of such assistance “ would entail a substantial reduction in his and his family ’s standard of living ” ) might apply to a court and ask to appoint him a defence counsel .
Article CARDINAL laid down the principle known as “ compulsory assistance of an advocate ” ( przymus adwokacki ) . That Article provided , in so far as relevant :

“ An accused must have a defence counsel [ of his own choice or officially appointed ] when a regional court is competent to deal with his case as a court of first instance . The counsel must take part in the main hearing ; he must also take part in any appellate hearing if the president of the court or the court itself has found this necessary . ”

Under LAW , the official appointment of a lawyer was valid as long as the proceedings lasted and , subject to explicit exceptions , an officially - appointed lawyer was also obliged to act on behalf of his client after the judgment became final . However , according to domestic practice which started after DATE ( the date on which a new cassation appeals procedure was introduced into the system of criminal justice ) , a lawyer had again to be officially appointed in cassation proceedings .

As from DATE , i.e. the date on which the relevant provisions of the PERSON of DATE on LAW to LAW and Other Criminal Statutes entered into force , a party to criminal proceedings might lodge a cassation appeal with ORG against any final decision of an appellate court which had terminated criminal proceedings .
Article CARDINALa § CARDINAL of the Code provided , in so far as relevant :

“ A cassation appeal may be lodged only on the grounds referred to in LAW [ these included a number of procedural irregularities , such as , for instance , incorrect composition of the trial court ; lack of legal assistance in cases where such assistance was compulsory ; breach of the rules governing jurisdiction in criminal matters ; trying a person in absentia in cases where his presence was obligatory and thus depriving him of an opportunity to defend himself , etc . ] or on the ground of another flagrant breach of law provided that the judicial decision in question was affected as a result of such a breach . No cassation appeal may be directed against the disproportionality of the penalty imposed . ”
LAW stipulated :
“ CARDINAL . NORP Parties to criminal proceedings shall be entitled to lodge a cassation appeal .
CARDINAL . A cassation appeal , which has been lodged by a party other than a prosecutor , shall be filed and signed by an advocate .

CARDINAL . Notice of a cassation appeal must be lodged with the court which has given the [ relevant ] decision within DATE from the date on which such decision was pronounced . The appeal itself must be lodged within DATE from the date on which the decision , together with the reasons therefor , was served on the party concerned . ”

Under LAW , the court which gave the decision appealed against was competent to decide whether the formal requirements for a cassation appeal had been complied with . If an accused ’s appeal was not filed and signed by an advocate , it had to be rejected on formal grounds . If such an appeal complied with the formal requirements , the case was referred to ORG .

At the relevant time , under LAW of DATE ( NORP karny wykonawczy ) , all correspondence of a person detained on remand was censored , unless a prosecutor or a court decided otherwise . No provision of the Code provided for a remedy enabling a detainee to contest the manner or scope of the application of that measure ( see , for reference , PERSON v. GPE , no . CARDINAL , § DATE , DATE ) .
